column2: CHAPTER XXXVI.
column3: CHAPTER thirty six.

column2: SEVENTY-TWO.
column3: SEVENTY TWO.

column2: On the next morning Phineas, with his speech before him, was obliged for a while to forget, or at least to postpone, Mr. Bonteen and his injuries.

column2: He could not now go to Lord Cantrip, as the hours were too precious to him, and, as he felt, too short.
column3: He could not now go to Lord Cantrip, as the hours were too precious to him, and, as he felt, too short.

column2: Though he had been thinking what he would say ever since the debate had become imminent, and knew accurately the line which he would take, he had not as yet prepared a word of his speech.
column3: Though he had been thinking what he would say ever since the debate had become imminent, and knew accurately the line which he would take, he had not as yet prepared a word of his speech.

column2: But he had resolved that he would not prepare a word otherwise than he might do by arranging certain phrases in his memory.
column3: But he had resolved that he would not prepare a word otherwise than he might do by arranging certain phrases in his memory.

column2: There should be nothing written; he had tried that before in old days, and had broken down with the effort.

column2: After a late breakfast he walked out far away, into the Regent's Park, and there, wandering among the uninteresting paths, he devised triumphs of oratory for himself.

column2: Let him resolve as he would to forget Mr. Bonteen, and that charge of having been untrue to his companions, he could not restrain himself from efforts to fit the matter after some fashion into his speech.

column2: Dim ideas of a definition of political honesty crossed his brain, bringing with him, however, a conviction that his thought must be much more clearly worked out than it could be on that day before he might venture to give it birth in the House of Commons.

column2: He entered the House with the Speaker at four o'clock, and took his seat without uttering a word to any man.

column2: He seemed to be more than ever disjoined from his party.

column2: At half-past four he was on his legs in the midst of a crowded House. The chance,--perhaps the hope,--of some such encounter as that of the former day, brought members into their seats, and filled the gallery with strangers.

column2: CHAPTER XXXVII.

column2: THE CONSPIRACY.

column2: On the morning following the great division Phineas was with his friend, Lord Cantrip, by eleven o'clock; and Lord Cantrip, when he had read the two letters in which were comprised the whole correspondence, made to our unhappy hero the following little speech. "I do not think that you can do anything.
column3: On the morning following the great division Phineas was with his friend, Lord Cantrip, by eleven o'clock; and Lord Cantrip, when he had read the two letters in which were comprised the whole correspondence, made to our unhappy hero the following little speech. "I do not think that you can do anything.

column2: Indeed, I am sure that Mr. Monk is quite right.
column3: Indeed, I am sure that mr Monk is quite right.

column2: I don't quite see what it is that you wish to do.
column3: I don't quite see what it is that you wish to do.

column2: Privately,--between our two selves,--I do not hesitate to say that Mr. Bonteen has intended to be ill-natured.
column3: Privately,--between our two selves,--I do not hesitate to say that mr Bonteen has intended to be ill natured.

column2: I fancy that he is an ill-natured--or at any rate a jealous--man; and that he would be willing to run down a competitor in the race who had made his running after a fashion different from his own.
column3: I fancy that he is an ill natured-or at any rate a jealous-man; and that he would be willing to run down a competitor in the race who had made his running after a fashion different from his own.

column2: Bonteen has been a useful man,--a very useful man; and the more so perhaps because he has not entertained any high political theory of his own.
column3: Bonteen has been a useful man,--a very useful man; and the more so perhaps because he has not entertained any high political theory of his own.

column2: You have chosen to do so,--and undoubtedly when you and Monk left us, to our very great regret, you did scuttle the ship."
column3: You have chosen to do so,--and undoubtedly when you and Monk left us, to our very great regret, you did scuttle the ship."
